sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• efficacy has not been established in the treatment of opioid-induced constipation in patients taking diphenylheptane opioids (eg, methadone)
  • Constipation - Irritable bowel syndrome: 8 mcg ORALLY twice daily with food and water; periodically assess need for continued treatment
  • Idiopathic constipation, chronic: 24 mcg ORALLY twice daily with food and water; periodically assess need for continued treatment
  • Opioid-induced constipation, in patients with chronic noncancer pain: 24 mcg ORALLY twice daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: no dosage adjustment needed
  • hepatic impairment (mild; Child-Pugh class A): no dosage adjustment needed
  • hepatic impairment (moderate; Child-Pugh class B): opioid-induced constipation; reduce initial dose to 16 mcg ORALLY twice daily; if tolerated and response not achieved, may increase to 24 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • hepatic impairment (severe; Child-Pugh class C): opioid-induced constipation; reduce initial dose to 8 mcg ORALLY twice daily; if tolerated and response not achieved, may increase to 24 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • hepatic impairment (moderate; Child-Pugh class B): chronic idiopathic constipation; 16 mcg ORALLY twice daily; if tolerated and response not achieved, may increase to 24 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • hepatic impairment (severe; Child-Pugh class C): chronic idiopathic constipation; 8 mcg ORALLY twice daily; if tolerated and response not achieved, may increase to 24 mg ORALLY twice daily
  • hepatic impairment (moderate; Child-Pugh class B): irritable bowel syndrome with constipation; no dosage adjustment needed
  • hepatic impairment (severe; Child-Pugh class C): irritable bowel syndrome with constipation; 8 mcg ORALLY once daily

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Constipation - Irritable bowel syndrome
  • Idiopathic constipation, chronic
  • Opioid-induced constipation, in patients with chronic noncancer pain

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: mechanical gastrointestinal obstruction, known or suspected

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• diarrhea, severe; avoid use
  • dyspnea has been reported; typically within 30 to 60 minutes of initial dose with resolution of symptoms within a few hours; recurrence with repeat dosing has been reported
  • hepatic impairment, moderate to severe (Child-Pugh class B or C); systemic drug exposure markedly increased; dose reduction recommended
  • mechanical gastrointestinal obstruction symptoms; confirm absence of obstruction prior to initiating therapy with lubiprostone

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal distension (3% to 6%), Abdominal pain (4% to 8%), Diarrhea (7% to 12%), Flatulence (4% to 6%), Nausea (8% to 29%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (2% to 11%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator that acts locally on the apical membrane of the gastrointestinal tract to increase intestinal fluid secretion and improve fecal transit. This action bypasses the antisecretory effects of opiates, which suppress secretomotor neuron excitability.

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono:
• Stomach and jejunum (presumed): rapid and extensive
  • Metabolite: M3 active
  • M3 metabolite, AUC, (hepatic impairment, moderate to severe): increased 119% (Child-Pugh Class B), increased 521% (Child-Pugh Class B)
  • M3 metabolite, Cmax, (hepatic impairment, moderate to severe): increased 66% (Child-Pugh Class B), increased 183% (Child-Pugh Class C)

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• Lubiprostone, plasma concentrations below level of quantitation
  • M3 metabolite: 0.9 to 1.4 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • swallow whole and do not chew or break apart
  • take with food and water

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• improvement in signs and symptoms of constipation is indicative of efficacy
  • reassess need for treatment; periodically
  • symptoms of mechanical obstruction; prior to treatment
  • increased incidence and severity of adverse effects in patients with severe hepatic impairment (Child-Pugh Class C) if dose escalated to full dosing regimen
  • diarrhea in breastfed infants

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
LUBIPROSTONE
USES: Lubiprostone is used to treat adult patients with chronic idiopathic constipation and irritable bowel syndrome with constipation. PHARMACOLOGY: Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator that acts locally to increase intestinal fluid secretion. It specifically activates the ClC2 receptor, a chloride channel that resides in the apical membrane of the intestine. Increased chloride-containing intestinal fluid secretion results, functioning to increase motility and the passage of stools through the intestine. Activation of ClC2 is independent of protein kinase A. In vitro studies have indicated that the activity of lubiprostone and its metabolites is primarily only on the apical (luminal) epithelium of the gastrointestinal tract. Sodium and potassium concentrations in the serum are not affected. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. TOXICITY: Overdose data is limited. The following adverse events were reported in 51 patients who received a single oral dose of 144 mcg of lubiprostone (6 times the normal single dose): nausea (45.1%), vomiting (27.5%), diarrhea (25.5%), dizziness (17.6%), loose or watery stools (13.7%), headache (11.8%), retching (7.8%), abdominal pain (5.9%), flushing (5.9%), dyspnea (3.9%), pallor (3.9%), stomach discomfort (3.9%), syncope (3.9%), upper abdominal pain (2%), anorexia (2%), asthenia (2%), chest discomfort (2%), dry mouth (2%), hyperhidrosis (2%), skin irritation (2%), and vasovagal episode (2%). ADVERSE EFFECTS: COMMON: Nausea, diarrhea, and headache. OTHER EFFECTS: Abdominal pain, flatulence, vomiting, dyspepsia, sinusitis, urinary tract infections, upper respiratory tract infection, dizziness, peripheral edema, fatigue, chest pain or discomfort, fever, arthralgia, back pain, pain in extremity, muscle cramp, dyspnea, cough, weight increase, depression, anxiety, insomnia, and hypertension.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
LUBIPROSTONE
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF MILD TO MODERATE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Correct any significant fluid and/or electrolyte abnormalities in patients with vomiting or diarrhea. MANAGEMENT OF SEVERE TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Severe toxicity is not expected after overdose of lubiprostone.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Lubiprostone undergoes minimal absorption from the gastrointestinal tract. Severe toxicity is not expected after overdose of lubiprostone. Gastrointestinal decontamination is generally not necessary. HOSPITAL: Lubiprostone undergoes minimal absorption from the gastrointestinal tract. Severe toxicity is not expected after overdose of lubiprostone. Gastrointestinal decontamination is generally not necessary. Consider activated charcoal only after very large ingestions or if coingestants with significant toxicity are involved.
  • Airway management: Should not be required in these cases.
  • Antidote: None.
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor vital signs in symptomatic patients. Monitor serum electrolytes in patients with severe vomiting and/or diarrhea.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: There is no information regarding the effectiveness of hemodialysis or hemoperfusion for the removal of lubiprostone from plasma. Since systemic absorption is minimal, methods to enhance systemic elimination are unlikely to be necessary.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: A patient with an inadvertent exposure, that remains asymptomatic can be managed at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Patients with a deliberate overdose, and those who are symptomatic, need to be monitored for several hours to assess electrolyte and fluid balance and gastrointestinal function. Patients that remain asymptomatic can be discharged. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients should be admitted for severe vomiting, profuse diarrhea, severe abdominal pain, dehydration, and electrolyte abnormalities. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a poison center or medical toxicologist for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is not clear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
LUBIPROSTONE
TOXICITY: Overdose data is limited. An adult took 96 mcg/day for 8 days without adverse effects. A 3-year-old ingested 7 or 8 capsules of lubiprostone (24 mcg each) and recovered. The following adverse events were reported in a Phase 1 cardiac repolarization study after 51 patients received a single oral dose of 144 mcg of lubiprostone (6 times the normal single dose): Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, loose or watery stools, headache, retching, abdominal pain, flushing, dyspnea, pallor, stomach discomfort, syncope, upper abdominal pain, anorexia, asthenia, chest discomfort, dry mouth, hyperhidrosis, skin irritation, and vasovagal episode. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: ADULTS: Chronic idiopathic constipation: 24 mcg orally twice daily. Irritable bowel syndrome with constipation: 8 mcg orally twice daily. CHILDREN: The safety and efficacy of lubiprostone have not been established in children.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report symptoms of severe nausea, diarrhea, or dyspnea.
  • Drug may cause abdominal distension or pain, diarrhea, flatulence, nausea, or headaches.
  • Instruct patient to take drug with food and water to reduce nausea.
